title: Seven Rules of Thumb for Web Site Experimenters
segmentation: Thank you and sorry for the delay here.
Again, this is joint work with Alex Roger an Yaesu.
So what are we trying to do here?
We're running thousands of experiments being if you visit Bing today, you're probably in two dozen experiments.
Um?
Lots of experience from Yahoo at LinkedIn Roger Workbook is consulting for booking.com and one of the questions that we asked is.
Can we generalize?
With so many experiments, so many interesting things, can we come up with some ideas to share with the Community?
And this is what this talk is really about.
These are generalizations in the sense that there are rules of thumb they're not provable.
They're usually wrong.
They usually write just like you know the rule of 72 for people that are familiar with it.
If you are looking at your interest rate, the money will double in about 72 / X and that works for a good range of values in around 4 to 12, which is where it's.
Thing.
All the examples are real user sample.
All the examples of at least 100,000 users, most of them have millions of users are all statistically significant.

I'll show you some really interesting results that we think of as breakthroughs for those we've run the multiple times to validate that this is just a not the .05 fluke, but rather something that we can prove using Fishers combined probability tests is a much much lower P value.
So let me start with rule #1.
Small changes can have a big impact to key metric.
Now.
It's very easy for small changes to have negative impact you have.
You're introducing a bug in the software.
We immediately see people abandoned.
We immediately see metrics go bad, so this is not interesting.
Our focus should be on positive differences.
Ken, are there examples where small changes make a big positive?
Impact the key metrics were also and also not interested in short-term novelty effects, so sometimes people ask me what do you mean by novelty effect?
And there's a really good example where in a TV show one of these QVC shopping network.
Standard lines is operator awaiting police.
Call now and you know you imagine this operators twiddling their thumbs just waiting for you to call, and Colleen sought change the call too.
If operators are busy, please call again.
So this creates this social proof that my card this product must be really good and when she did that she broke the 20 year sales record in the show.
But that works only once or twice.
This is not something that's going to work if you do it on every shelf, so we're interested in long term effects.
So let me show you some.
You know this is sort of the obligatory obligatory part of the talk, which is to show you some cool examples.
Here's one.
Two versions of Bing.
And you can barely tell the difference.
Right, so I'll make it.
A little bit easier, still pretty hard to see.
But the one on the right has slightly darker Blues.
It has slightly darker green and slightly lighter Blacks for the captions.
What we're trying to do is basically get the user eyes to focus on the links that matter.
OK, so tiny change.
Think about what this takes to do this right?
You go into the CSV file.
Sorry into the CSS file, you change a several numbers in there.
Very simple change.
What does it do?
Success rate improves time to success, improves and we make another $10,000,000 a year.
Right, so when these things first come out with like OK, this must be a fluke and we run them again and again and we look for long-term effect.
And this is true, like this is a true result that happened to us fairly amazing.
Another example that I picked from Amazon is showing the right offer at the right time.
At Amazon I was director of Personalization and the home page was what was called self optimizing you could introduce.
Ideas into the slots on the home page and there was one thing that kept winning.
It was the credit card offer and it was really annoying because we knew that the click click through it was just terrible on those and people hated them.
Was just making us a lot of money.
So what we did is we moved it.
We moved it to the shopping cart and we moved it in a way that is sort of basic math for kids.
Which is you've got $32 in your shopping cart.
If you get the Amazon credit card you will only have to pay $2.
Right, sort of very convincing picture.
Ran the experiment 10s of millions of dollars.
In profit mind you, Amazon is P of almost infinite, so this makes a big difference for Amazon.
Another example is anti malware.

You know we're running a very lucrative business when you install freeware, it tries to latch onto some search pages and shows things there do not really belong into Bing so you can see here and here.
These are ads that are uncertain by malware.
We're not really producing them, so you know somebody worked over the weekend, block the calls to change the Dom and it was unbelievable.
It's like people started.
Visit us more session success rate went up type this is.
All our key metrics improve by significant significant amounts, and this is a change that wasn't planned for six months.
A big project.
This was something.
Relatively small so breakthroughs happen.
We've documented them.
We've confirmed over and over that they happen, but they are rare.
You know, maybe one in 501 in 1000 experiments, one in 2000.
Experiments happen to be this thing.
That really is a breakthrough and there's a risk that the org will focus on them.
People will try these things that will say maybe they'll breakthrough.
And it's hard to get them done, so this is where rule #2 comes in.
Most of the changes that we introduce.
Rarely have big positive impact.
OK, so if you look at the progress that we're making.
It's inch by inch.
It's a lot of people working a lot of time for these.
You know half a percent to 1% improvement.
And when you look at it, you introduce you know one or two percent every month.
Improvements are revenue improvements to key metrics.
After year, you suddenly make 2030% more money.
Right, suddenly the user metrics are looking a lot better, so most improvements are done this way.
And it's important to highlight that I'm talking about the really high level metric that the OR cares about.
It's very easy to focus on something.
In a specific query, and so I've managed to improve the X query by a lot.
That happens also once you dilute it to the overall impact.
Those tend to be rare and most of the effects are really really small.
If you look out there, we see a lot of breakthroughs that appear initially that they might be interesting in the two sources.
For that one is you should expect them from the statistics if you run your statistics at the standard, you know .05 P value.
We run thousands of experiments.
You should expect a lot of false positives.
And the second one that happens is just some bad design of the experiment.
Some anomaly people will log something wrong.
We've had experiment where people will log their revenue twice.
Well, that's likely to generate a really nice breakthrough.
So always be careful of those.

And one thing that we're starting to think about more and more is this idea that when you do standard hypothesis testing, what you're really computing is the probability of the data given the hypothesis, right?
We assume the null we say.
What is the probably the data, but that's not really what we want.
What we really want is the opposite, which is what is the probability that my hypothesis is true or false given the data.
And for that you have to apply Bayes rule on a.
You know you guys all know all this.
Well I just want to give you a concrete example which is at Microsoft.
We sort of have a success rate of about a third on experiments.
Most experiments actually fail, so if you have a success rate of about a third and you apply Bayes rule, something is .05 statistically significant.
You should believe that you know it's likely to be true because of that 89% Bayes rule.
Now, what happens if you think you got a breakthrough?
Right, somebody says I just doubled revenue.
OK, or somebody says I moved sessions per user, which is one of our key metrics.
It's very, very hard to move well.

If you think it's a breakthrough in the probability of a breaker is 1 in 500, then even if you got a stat SIG result with .05, this is what you should believe in that this is really only going to be 3.1% true.
OK, big difference.
You know, so a few colors from that.
If you think about the Bayes rule and our success rate, one of them is following.
Tail lights is easy, right?
We have all ideas.
We try them out.
We don't have a great success rate.
It's a third overall Microsoft Bing.
It's even lower because we've optimized it for awhile.

We're about 10 to 20% successful, but if you think an idea that's out there that's launched by one of the competitors, they've gone through this process, they have run through a lot of ideas that failed and they launched something that appears to be successful.
So we always try to look at what other people are doing and it goes in both directions.
When we launch a very successful feature, we see that the competitors are launching it.
This.
Overtime as law comes in, any feature, any figure, and you know this is an old article from the 1890s.
So he means basically any statistics that looks interesting or different is usually wrong.
This is amazingly true.
You'll be shocked how often it happens.
You know, if we look at sessions per user, you know this is our North Star metric.
Most experiments by far don't move it or they move it very little.

So when somebody comes along and says I moved sessions per user by 2%, I'm just going to point that Wyman law and say look, this is so many standard deviations off 8 standard deviations off the probability that this happened is 180 -- 15.
You don't win the lottery twice in a row.
Let's check whether this really makes sense and we usually find mistakes.
Now, and this is no different than you know, somebody came to you with the proof that P equals NP these days, right?
You're not going to stop eating.
You're not going to stop doing what you're doing.
You're probably going to send the reviewer and say, hey, here's another crazy guy that thinks he found P equals NP.
You know, give them the template with regards to your proof.
The first major errors on page X.
So there's a bunch of examples here.
I'm not going to go through them again there online.
Let me go.
Just conclude I showed you the two rules that we came up with.
Here's a list of a few more.
Your mileage will vary.
We see a lot of stories out there of success.
Is most of them do not replicate and this applies to some of the climens law and other things that we see out there.
Speed matters a lot.
This is a lovely statement that we were making if we showed through experimentation.
If you can improve.
The performance of being on the server by 10 millisecond you paid for your annual salary.
Reducing abandonment is hard.
It's very easy to shift clicks from one place to another.
It's very hard to reduce the abandonment.
We like simple designs, lots of companies out there to multi variable testing.
Very complex thing.
We like to iterate fast, do small things and then learn from them.
It tends to work a lot better and then rule #7 is sort of you have to have enough users.

There's statistics both books out there that say you have 30 central Limit theorem kicks in but we're really looking at tail events and for that you need a lot more so we have a table in the paper with some examples of how skewed metrics are and why you need a lot more.
Users than you might think.
Thank you.
